text:
Lyrics:

Love
bonds of sea and fire
floating in the sea,
travelling across the great distance
even the flames of the war cannot
break the love of those
who found true peace in their soul

I 
want to know where this
love is leading me
through the violence of the great war
I see a new peace
light shines through the dark
abyss of no return
through the ocean and the flames

boyfriend, 
do you hear me?
where are you now?
far away, 
but even death can't separate us 
from each other
that's true love
I saw you 
through the darkness
you dreamt of me
now our arms are crossing
through the distance
I can feel you
a part of me
you're inside me!

author: boone pickens

text:
Xenogears=my favorite game of all time
At first some plot elements are thrown to the player in a confusing way,  but it all makes sense in the end. Xenogears is a story spanning several millennia that involves four different incarnations of the Contact and the Antitype, heroes that actually have flaws and feel human, heartwrenching drama scenes, villains that are just heroes in disguise, visuals that most people criticize but I like more than those of FF7, an absolutely awesome OST, lots of character development not only for Fei, but also for other important characters like Elly, Citan, Bart and even the "big bads" Ramsus, Grahf and Krelian and a heartwrenching ending which is neither happy nor sad (Fei saved Elly and the world, but the destruction of the Zohar prevented Gears and technology from working, so the world is now in a state almost as bleak as how it would have been if Deus had succeeded in absorbing all humans), and I wish that Square Enix made a Xenogears HD remaster for the PS4 with a new battle system, improved visuals and all the cut content being an actual part of the game instead of being explained to us in a 30-minute cutscene or completely omitted, even at the cost of having three discs (The El-Regrs for example: I loved Elly so much and I wish I could play as her in her Omnigear)!
I'm so sad Italian JRPG fans have never seen this masterpiece of a game coming to their country and I wish Square Enix could make another story like this one for FF16, or perhaps rename FF16 the Xenogears HD remaster so that Italian FF fans may play it. Please, Square, remember what you once were and give me a Xenogears HD remaster!
author: Vittorio Pugliese

text: concordo su tutte le proposte! pazzesco che sia nato e cresciuto con i jrpg anni '90 e di questo capolavoro sono venuto a conoscenza solo recentemente. peccato non  averci giocato ma ho seguito la storia e me ne sono innamorato. davvero bello vedere che la grandezza di questo gioco vive nei cuori di tantissimi
author: matteobraso

text:
Un altro italiano che gioca a Xenogears? Impressionante! Non vedo l'ora di poterne incontrare uno dal vivo (ho un conoscente che si chiama Andrea Setti ed √® un gran appassionato di Final Fantasy 7 e 8, ma Xenogears l'ha conosciuto solo grazie a me). Non so perch√©, ma in Italia dei JRPG se ne sa cos√¨ poco chedi tutta la mia scuola (non della classe, proprio di tutta la scuola) io sono l'unico che nel 2017 ancora gioca a Final Fantasy 7 e 8, che sono giochi pi√π vecchi di me!
Mi dispiace di essere un 2000 e quindi di essermi perso l'era dei grandi JRPG della PS1 (da me soprannominati anche "romanzi interattivi" per la loro storia e i loro personaggi ben costruiti), per√≤ sto recuperando tutti i grandi JRPG di fine anni 90-inizio 2000 e devo ammettere che molti di essi sono tra i miei giochi preferiti. Meno male che sta cominciando una nuova era di JRPG sulla PS4, perch√© quelli della 1 me li sono persi! Oltre a Xenogears gioco anche a FF7-8, Chrono Trigger (per me fortemente sopravvalutato perch√© l'ho giocato dopo Xenogears e quindi non sono riuscito ad apprezzarlo come lo apprezzano i fan), Chrono Trigger Crimson Echoes (ci vuole l'emulatore se lo vuoi scaricare, ma √® molto meglio di Trigger), Chrono Cross, Final Fantasy Tactics e Suikoden 2. Tu quali JRPG hai?
author: Vittorio Pugliese

author: Bloody

text: I honestly think this is the most amazing melody ever written. I have been trying to figure out what makes it so brilliant, that initial flute melody. It's on a pentatonic scale of the first 5 notes of the A major scale but the bass sits on E and it all actually suggests E dorian given the c-sharp, backed up by the bass using the tonic, subdominant and dominant of E, but nowhere in the melody or the backing is the third of E minor used, so it all hints at E dorian while never confirming it, hovering round that magical I - IV chord progression that the dorian mode has, kind of permanently pushing at it, and it all just hovers between two scales like a dream. It consumes me.
author: Sasarai

text: I appreciate this song for the exact same reason. I feel a typical asian vibe from this use of the pentatonic scale. other great examples are the Evil Forest theme from FFIX or something from FFXII

text: It was largely incomplete, the Game. The book details everything that the developers wanted to incorporate but couldn't due to their fund being siphoned to another project. (I forget which Final Fantasy took precedent, It was either 8 or 9.) That being said, even with it's hastened work towards the end of Disk One and the entire of Disk 2 the game itself is emotional. The characters and their struggles, their growth and their personal demons that they need to overcome. While some get a smaller demon to face (In relation to Rico and Billy) Others have long term and much more character defining ones. Maria, Citan, Fei, Bart and Elly.

author: Pogopope

text: I was about to write about how awesome the game is, but in the end the comment from @Emad sums it best. The game is such an impressive combination of jaw-dropping and original stuff that it's extremely hard to find something else that even come comes close to it. Of course it's a stretch to say it's the best game ever, but this would be true for anything and any game. A book has been published after the game came out, titled Xenogears: Perfect Works, which explain a lot of the universe the designers had created for the game. This alone gives a feeling of how well thought-out the game has been. Personally, the perfect combination of the thought-provoking and mature story, plot, narrative and music are what creates this killer game. On top of that, you have mechas, plenty of wtf and epic moments, anime-style art and cutscenes, world map, non-linear exploration (jumping), two different types of battles, two minigames... they don't do games like this anymore.

text: Mitsuda-san allegedly composed this particular piece whilst asleep and dreaming.  I doubt it not.
author: Ben Trovato

text:
I do recall a semi-lucid dream or two I had where my creative faculties felt markedly more potent than they were in waking life. For a talented and well-educated musician to be able to produce whole works while dreaming seems very plausible. 

I'd actually wager it's a fairly common occurrence. I guess one of the biggest challenges would be in managing to retain the melody and notation as your brainwaves accelerate and your waking consciousness takes precedence. It does seem to have a certain ethereal quality about it.

author: amyfan’£÷Ö÷Ö÷Ö

text:
+Chris Theo apples and oranges, neither Xenosaga nor Xenoblade can be considered spiritual sequels to this masterpiece in any way. Perhaps the title made you think of them? the only thing they have in common is the director and that they all have a sci-fi setting, but alas that is where the similiarities end. 

Most of the key staff that worked with him at square either stayed or moved on to other projects. I get that these games have a cult following around the world, but I feel that Xenogears does not have match in the JRPG world in terms of story. Gameplaywise is another story though, I wish they would have all kept the chrono trigger gameplay intact.
author: Lion heart

text:
Xenosaga was a reimagining of Xenogears, and in fact there are a good number of similarities and links between them, despite their timelines and universes being separate.

Xenoblade was a separate title altogether - originally called 'Monado', but later renamed in an homage/allusion to the Xenoverse. I think it is the realisation of Takahashi's desire to create a game for a younger audience, in addition to a crystallisation of his knowledge and experiences as to what makes a good 'game'. But I think reading between the lines, he was disappointed that there doesn't seem to be much of a mass market for more complex, personal games like the prior two.

text:
I dare you to find a single game out today that even comes close to how amazing this game is, the soundtrack by the legendary Yasunori Mitsuda (Chrono T/C, FF etc) is just imo the best of his work.

The story is so mind boggling and hard to grasp at first but once you do, you realize how it all fits into place in such a beautiful way. All the characters are lovable and get their own shine time and development to which makes you really connect with them emotionally, and the battle system never got old at all.

Its such a shame this game was rushed through disc 2 cause of production, it still is my #1

text: I can't find a better game, but this one is definitely my favorite, even though I haven't been able to beat it. My memory cards are jacked up, so I can't save my progress. Have any suggestions on how to defeat the calamity gear? I learned the hard way that you're supposed to upgrade the gears, and well.... yeah. Any advice you could give?
author: Miaka Kemp

text: @Miaka Kemp¬†Calamity Gear is the least of your worries regarding tough bosses, but basically you don't really need levels, just to upgrade the gears from Balthasar, fight around and gain money/sell some equipment you don't need, it's just a simple button mash for that fight, no strategy needed.
author: Emad YS

text: Least of my worries? Oh man, I'm screwed. Thanks for the advice, because I'm going to need it!
author: Miaka Kemp

text: @Miaka Kemp¬†Not to demoralize you, I struggled at calamity back when I was 12 along with other bosses (27 now) the only truly frustrating points where the boss fights when you try to reflect the beam off the ship, and when you try to halt the advance of the gibler? army. The latter is annoying because you have to go through a sequence of screens and is a bit of time from when you last saved.¬†
author: Emad YS

text: That's alright. I'm trying to get as much tips for when I play again. I'll just need to get new memory cards so I can save my progress. And to be prepared to rip out my hair lol.

text:
Well back in the day it was just enjoyable, I didn't fully understand the story back then, was quite young.

However I played Xenogears about 5 times before I fully got the whole thing and reading through that background story book thing.
author: Emad YS

text:
@Minnan1 Looking back, Xenogears feels like the next step from Chrono Trigger in some ways. Chrono Trigger was revolutionary for that brief moment in time and Xenogears took many of the attributes that made CT so great and then evolved the battle system and story beyond what any other console game had attempted.¬†


The fact that Yasunori Mitsuda composed the soundtrack might be the biggest reason why I loved this game so much. He got his first chance at Squaresoft to compose the soundtrack for Chrono Trigger and really blew gamers away with the music he wrote for Xenogears. Most of us didn't realize it at the time, but the music score Mitsuda wrote was the driving force behind the strong feelings and nostalgia we feel for Xenogears.

text:
@jetser24 
It's kinda sad... video game music can be as good as movie soundtracks (it all depends on the composer's talent, really). I remember someone saying that he played Rose of May (from FF9) before his teachers at a conservatory. At first, the teachers were all "It's beautiful." and then this person told them it was from a video game and all of sudden, the teachers began to retract. Some people are clearly fixated on not recognizing VG's artistic value for some dumb reason.

author: skykid

text:
Completely agree with Idolores.  The story blew every other RPG in history out of the water, but their budget got too tight.  There are many things wrong with Xenogears, but there are many MORE things right with it.  It stands as the greatest RPG of all time, despite the flaws.

That said, I would be scared of a remake... scared they would try to do more than just upgrade the graphics and fill out the second disc.

author: pianoguy222

text: amen.. true gamers, specially rpgist do NOT need bad ass graphics to have fun.. just needs a good story and good character connections.. well said
author: g0d53nd

text: Actually, there are no new games at the moment that are just awesome. But I did enjoy ShadowHearts1 and ShadowHearts2 and recommend giving them a go, they were definately entertaining! (Shadowhearts3 just didn't do it for me) Of course there is the ever so awesome Suikoden series. Lately, I've just been doing the mmo thing. Either UO or WoW, depending on my mood. And even with that said, I've never seen a game to top Xenogears every, even with the sad letdown of disc 2.
author: LadyKaliska

text: the philosophies of the game are quite honestly escaping me at this moment. that's how big the scope of the game was! that level of commitment to a certain extent is what i feel that's missing in recent rpgs. well, i take that back, because i probably made statements like that back in year 2000 or something lol. and at the time, there were just so many mediocre rpgs. i admit i don't know enough of more recent rpgs, which i've played little of except titans i.e. - ffxii.
author: John Wu

text: i have to say it's one of the only rpgs where i still have to think how best to explain to someone in a brief logline, which certainly says something about the ambition of the people who made it. when i bought it, i bought it with the premature impression that it's just a "game to play until ff7 comes out" (or did it come soon after ff7? i don't quite remember) ironically, i thought that ff7 was truly something special, xenogears will always be above it in my mind.
author: John Wu

text: You don't sound like a dork. Actually *blushes* when my husband was dating me, he sent me his copy of Xenogears for me to play through. That game was just an experience for me, period. I remember going to school and staring off into space contemplating the philosphies of that game. Even though it's been years since I've played, it's one of the few games that's just stuck with me.
author: LadyKaliska

text: yes, i've always been a fan of sprites. specifically in chrono trigger, this game of course, secret of mana. i think the appeal of sprites is in its ability to provide nuances but still leave character behavior to your imagination. the fighting poses and choreography in xenogears is pretty damn detailed! and the "victory poses" have a lot of charm because their body language tells a story of who they are (the way elly flips her hair back, or aeris breathes a sigh of relief after a fight)
author: John Wu

text: haha strangely enough i rather like having a 2 disc collection...except with my used copy of shenmue on dreamcast. the console always froze everytime i changed discs =( anyway, i remember thinking it funny back then that billy's gear was the only one with that yellow cape on it (correct me if i'm wrong). don't get me wrong though, his gear still rocks, and so does this game! =) the music for the opening sequence was part of my cardio playlist and i don't care if i sound like a dork haha
author: John Wu

text: Of course... the lines would have to be the same, everything would have to be the same, everything just FF10 style, would be rather nice, except it would probably have to be 2 discs long even for the new games. *goes off to drool in a corner somewhere* Can you imagine the gear battles. *dies*
author: LadyKaliska

text: And that game was able to evoke every emotion without us being able to see the character's emotions. You could just feel it. That's what makes it such an awesome game. The background colors were nice too. I also enjoyed the controls and how every boss battle was not the same. I liked being on foot and in the gear. I don't need the game characters looking like a human/top graphics to have a damned good time. That's not to say I wouldn't like to see a redone Xenogears with the graphics of today
author: LadyKaliska

text: See that's the problem. The graphic-tards outnumber us people with good taste and now we have all these dumb games not worth the 30+ hours you put into them (there are a few gems). I agree. I thought the graphics were fine and alot of game shop employees (not all) but alot, think they are like elite... gamers just for working there or something. Trust me as a girl gamer, going in and talking to them causes a headache. I always liked the sprite look, because to me, it's a game.
author: LadyKaliska

text: hahahaha, you know, i'm a huge fan of this game but i do have to concede that i loved the battle system on foot as well. as far as the gears, i think i managed to overlook just how relatively simplistic it was compared to the sheer joy of customizing your moves on foot (and it's just a heck of a lot more fun if you ask me). while i certainly don't hate it, yeah it would've been interesting to see what else they could've done with it.
author: John Wu

text: you know what's interesting though. people can say what they want about how xenogears aged in terms of now meaning 2008. but i remember even in something like 1999 or 2000, i've heard some game shop employees complaining about the graphics, which is weird because i never really thought of it as a bad-looking game by any stretch of the imagination back then. in fact, i think the sprites have a lot of charm and i loved the backgrounds as far as artistry is concerned.
author: John Wu

text: I KNOW! The first time I played through, I needed to play the second disc twice until the lightbulb started to turn on in my head. The writer of that story was a GENIUS! Even nowadays, the movies we watch, or the tv series that's on tv... all fall so short. Xenogears in terms of plot has spoiled me. Great romance but not mushy and annoying (even the guys like Fei and Elly together ^_^ and Fei isn't an EMO YAY!), adventure, philosphy... just everything!!! Xenogears has spoilt this girl gamer.
author: LadyKaliska

text: I agree, I love xenogears though the plot gets extremely confusing due to complicated metaphors and plot twists, I'd love to play it again to see what I can get out of it....
author: Kurosawaisgod

text: It's sad that people tends to focus too much on graphics nowadays. I still prefer classic games like in this list over what people calls today  "epic".

text: It's sad how good rpg storylines have given way to graphics. Over the years the better the graphics have gotten, the storylines and the creativity of the characters have gone down the tubes. Xenogears is one of my favorite all time rpgs, the storyline is phenomanal and everytime I play it I get something new out of it. I'll take that over graphics anyday hands down!!!

text: Yea this is not definite no more for alot of reasons, one is the upcoming gamers. text: personally i think this game was too long, and i had an extremely hard time keeping my interest with it. i thought the battle system for when you where on foot was AWESOME but i hated the gears so much. but all in all still an absolute masterpiece.
author: HydraulicSandwich

text: This is by far the best game on the PS one, and among the greatest(if not the greatest) RPGs of all time.
author: Idtelos

text: Most Definitely, I agree that Yasunori Mitsuda's compositions are much better than Nobuo Uematsu.
author: Idtelos

text: I like him better too.  CT, Xenogears and CC were all epic soundtracks.  Chrono Cross is my favorite of his.  I have both the CC and Xenogears soundtracks.  Xenogears has my favorite plot of any game ever though.  My runner-up would be FFT (screw EGM and their inability to comprehend the plot).
author: Satan's Taint

text: Hey....we all have our opinions, I'd have to say I adore Nobuo Uemastu's masterpieces but that Yasunori Mitsuda guy I can't say because I never really heard his music....besides maybe this.
author: Milk Duds

text: I know I might catch some heat for this, but I think Yasunori Mitsuda might be better than Nobuo Uematsu. Almost all of Mitsuda's RPG themes invokes an emotional response with me. Xenogears and Chrono Cross were definitely his two best works.
author: Sean Saunders

text: man, if you guys only knew how much i love this game. ill take this story, setting, and characters over fancy graphics anyday
